div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The New York Times, June 5, 1901
div1.p:
Yellow Fever Spread Broadcast by
Their Bite, Says a Son of
Dr. Finlay.

Among the passengers who arrived from
Havana on the Ward Line steamship Morro
Castle yesterday was Dr. C. E. Finlay, a
son of Dr. C. J. Finlay, the author of the
theory that mosquitoes spread yellow fe-
ver. Dr. Finlay, speaking of his father's
work yesterday, said:

“Among scientists there is but little
doubt now that yellow fever is spread by
the common house mosquito, which be-
longs to the species called Culex. These
insects bite a person suffering from the
disease and then inject the poison into
some one else. In this way alone is the
disease spread, and if the mosquitoes could
be exterminated yellow fever would be at
an end. The frost kills the mosquitoes in
the South, and there is no yellow fever
there until another crop of mosquitoes ap-
pears. There are always cases of yellow
fever in Cuba, and the insect, therefore, is
able to find subjects from which they
inoculate others with the poison.

“My father, when he discovered that
mosquitoes spread yellow fever, caught one
of the pests, and after starving the insect
for two days, allowed it to bite himself.
This test, however, was not a good one, as
he is an immune, and then the same test
was applied to a subject who was sus-
ceptible to the disease. The latter con-
tracted the fever in this way, and then
hundreds of similar experiments followed,
and all the subjects developed yellow fe-
ver.

“This clearly demonstrated the accuracy
of the theory that yellow fever is not con-
tagious, but is simply spread by mosquitoes
just as malaria is spread by another spe-
cies of mosquitoes that lives in the swamps.
As soon as a culex has bitten a sufferer
from yellow fever, the insect is caught and
bottled for a couple of days, and then
when hungry is put upon a subject. Dr.
Lazier, one of the Yellow Fever Commis-
sion, who died under the experiment, al-
lowed himself to be bitten by five or six
mosquitoes, and in that way got an un-
usually heavy inoculation.

“As the experiments proceed, it is be-
lieved that in time a virus obtained from
either a patient or a culex will be pro-
cured which, when modified, can be used
as successfully as bovine virus is for small-
pox. There are only four or five cases of
yellow fever in Havana at the present time,
but the season is on, and unless the house
mosquito of the culex species is eradi-
cated, no matter how well the city is
cleaned and sewered, there will always be
cases of yellow fever in the city.”
